data.author: Piemaker
data.content: When Mr Cohen states in February 25, that the first kiln is fired up, with the rest online by the end of 25. And here we are, 1 Kiln that could run at 40t a day, taken offline and optimised, now doing 45t a day. The rest of the kilns?. Well we know in September they were waiting for parts from India, for kiln 2, the rest? And this set up is new and fandangelled, and will increase production. So February was a sales pitch to get money in. The reality is one kiln works grossing $9-10k gross, the time and money spent on modernisation has never been clear, but now looks happless. How are they going to fund the final 2 tranches? We know the next one is taken care of, but then? Because they sure aren’t making any money. The bank loan, $4m. How much revenue does it make to make at what margin makes this affordable? The $80k a year logistics profit, the net on the 34.5% share of revenue $3k a day gross. Or are they going to have to come back cap in hand for more? It’s going to take a lot more than 1 kiln and a good sales pitch. Perhaps it’s time for a change in leadership.

data.author: Lithman
data.content: Google search: Hydrated lime is generally more expensive than quicklime per pound because it is a processed product, but quicklime may be more cost-effective for large-scale use due to its higher density, which lowers transportation costs. The final price depends on quantity, brand, and application. Processing cost: Hydrated lime is quicklime with water added, a processing step that adds to its cost. Density: Quicklime is more dense than hydrated lime. This means for the same volume, quicklime has a higher weight. For large purchases, this can make quicklime cheaper per tonne because there are lower transportation and storage costs. Application: The overall cost comparison also depends on the specific application. For example, hydrated lime is often sold in smaller bags for specific uses, while quicklime might be purchased in bulk for industrial purposes. Product availability: Quicklime is the raw material, while hydrated lime is a finished product that has been chemically altered, which also contributes to a higher per-unit price.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: Firering, by my estimations are sat on roughly $2.44m - $1,000,000 (Ricca) - $1,154,790 (Recent raise of £0.86m) - $290,000 (Expected with Ricca selling asset) The next 2 tranches come to $1,963,334. I’m assuming some of the remaining will go towards running costs over the next 3 months. That really only leaves the July 31st Tranche of $1,033,333 to find in ~5 months. More time for them to get Kiln 2 producing, more time for Kiln 1 to add to the inventory that already sits around 5000t (~$1,000.000 at $200/t). =============== References/Workings Below: =============== Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/updated-agreement-to-acquire-quicklime-project-l3ar5frikeolmlb.html - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and - an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333. “Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to announce that it has received US$1m in full and final settlement of all debts and claims owed by Ricca. In addition, Firering announces the closing of a placing and subscription raising a further £0.86 m (the "Placing" and "Subscription"). “ Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/fundraising-and-limeco-operations-update-60tbcon53oov2dy.html - Received $1,000,000 from Ricca - £860,000 from placing which is roughly $1,154,790 “As stated previously, Firering also expects that Ricca will make a distribution of net proceeds to Ricca's shareholders following completion of the sale of a subsidiary asset for A$4.4 million (approximately £2.2 million), subject to an adjustment of up to A$332,000 (approximately £166,000) payable to Skylark Minerals Limited (ASX: SKM) (Skylark). Firering holds a 10.6 percent shareholding in Ricca.” Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/ricca-resources-us1m-settlement-finalised-h6cfhczw7semxmk.html - £2.2m minus the £166,000 is £2,034,000 - 10.6 % of £2m is £215,604 - That’s roughly $290,000

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: The shareholder loan of US$104,546,336‡ is what will be paid back to shareholders (Firering, Clearglass Investments Limited ("Clearglass") and Kai Group Ltd) once, I assume, Limeco is fully operational and profitable. It's an asset and would be paid back before dividends with the benefit of avoiding tax. In simplistic terms, it's tax free dividends. Currently Firering have 30.7% of that asset, hopefully rising to 45% by July. Money in the bank for the January tranche, we have until 30th April to get the next payment together. Hopefully by selling quicklime etc, or Bank loan. Last report would be a raise. · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and · an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333.

data.content: When Mr Cohen states in February 25, that the first kiln is fired up, with the rest online by the end of 25. Well we know in September they were waiting for parts from India, for kiln 2, the rest? And this set up is new and fandangelled, and will increase production. So February was a sales pitch to get money in. The reality is one kiln works grossing $9-10k gross, the time and money spent on modernisation has never been clear, but now looks happless. How are they going to fund the final 2 tranches? We know the next one is taken care of, but then? Because they sure aren’t making any money. The bank loan, $4m. How much revenue does it make to make at what margin makes this affordable? The $80k a year logistics profit, the net on the 34.5% share of revenue $3k a day gross. Or are they going to have to come back cap in hand for more? It’s going to take a lot more than 1 kiln and a good sales pitch. Perhaps it’s time for a change in leadership.

data.content: Great news indeed, but I'm surprised by the muted response. The possibility of a placing to pay the January 2026 Limeco option has been dragging the share price down for some time. Now the finance for that is sorted, it means we have almost 6 months until the next Limeco option payment at the end of April. With kiln 1 operating at 55% and kiln 2 coming on line in December, then come the new year we'll be operating at a profit and generating a significant income stream ($5M per annum?) I'm looking forward to an update on the kiln 2 progress, and then the activation of kilns 3 and 4 in the new year, at which point we could be generating around $10M per annum. Then the remaining 4 kilns can be activated and the concrete facility constructed.

data.author: Lithman
data.content: Google search: Hydrated lime is generally more expensive than quicklime per pound because it is a processed product, but quicklime may be more cost-effective for large-scale use due to its higher density, which lowers transportation costs. The final price depends on quantity, brand, and application. Processing cost: Hydrated lime is quicklime with water added, a processing step that adds to its cost. Density: Quicklime is more dense than hydrated lime. This means for the same volume, quicklime has a higher weight. For large purchases, this can make quicklime cheaper per tonne because there are lower transportation and storage costs. Application: The overall cost comparison also depends on the specific application. For example, hydrated lime is often sold in smaller bags for specific uses, while quicklime might be purchased in bulk for industrial purposes. Product availability: Quicklime is the raw material, while hydrated lime is a finished product that has been chemically altered, which also contributes to a higher per-unit price.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: Firering, by my estimations are sat on roughly $2.44m - $1,000,000 (Ricca) - $1,154,790 (Recent raise of £0.86m) - $290,000 (Expected with Ricca selling asset) The next 2 tranches come to $1,963,334. I’m assuming some of the remaining will go towards running costs over the next 3 months. That really only leaves the July 31st Tranche of $1,033,333 to find in ~5 months. More time for them to get Kiln 2 producing, more time for Kiln 1 to add to the inventory that already sits around 5000t (~$1,000.000 at $200/t). =============== References/Workings Below: =============== Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/updated-agreement-to-acquire-quicklime-project-l3ar5frikeolmlb.html - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and - an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333. “Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to announce that it has received US$1m in full and final settlement of all debts and claims owed by Ricca. In addition, Firering announces the closing of a placing and subscription raising a further £0.86 m (the "Placing" and "Subscription"). “ Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/fundraising-and-limeco-operations-update-60tbcon53oov2dy.html - Received $1,000,000 from Ricca - £860,000 from placing which is roughly $1,154,790 “As stated previously, Firering also expects that Ricca will make a distribution of net proceeds to Ricca's shareholders following completion of the sale of a subsidiary asset for A$4.4 million (approximately £2.2 million), subject to an adjustment of up to A$332,000 (approximately £166,000) payable to Skylark Minerals Limited (ASX: SKM) (Skylark). Firering holds a 10.6 percent shareholding in Ricca.” Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/ricca-resources-us1m-settlement-finalised-h6cfhczw7semxmk.html - £2.2m minus the £166,000 is £2,034,000 - 10.6 % of £2m is £215,604 - That’s roughly $290,000

data.content: The shareholder loan of US$104,546,336‡ is what will be paid back to shareholders (Firering, Clearglass Investments Limited ("Clearglass") and Kai Group Ltd) once, I assume, Limeco is fully operational and profitable. It's an asset and would be paid back before dividends with the benefit of avoiding tax. In simplistic terms, it's tax free dividends. Currently Firering have 30.7% of that asset, hopefully rising to 45% by July. Money in the bank for the January tranche, we have until 30th April to get the next payment together. Hopefully by selling quicklime etc, or Bank loan. data.author: BenBaccon
data.content: Great news indeed, but I'm surprised by the muted response. The possibility of a placing to pay the January 2026 Limeco option has been dragging the share price down for some time. Now the finance for that is sorted, it means we have almost 6 months until the next Limeco option payment at the end of April. With kiln 1 operating at 55% and kiln 2 coming on line in December, then come the new year we'll be operating at a profit and generating a significant income stream ($5M per annum?) The original plan was a loan from a Zambian bank to cover the Limeco options ($2M outstanding) Surely this should now be approved given the consistent revenue being generated? I'm looking forward to an update on the kiln 2 progress, and then the activation of kilns 3 and 4 in the new year, at which point we could be generating around $10M per annum. Then the remaining 4 kilns can be activated and the concrete facility constructed.

data.author: Lithman
data.content: Google search: Hydrated lime is generally more expensive than quicklime per pound because it is a processed product, but quicklime may be more cost-effective for large-scale use due to its higher density, which lowers transportation costs. The final price depends on quantity, brand, and application. Processing cost: Hydrated lime is quicklime with water added, a processing step that adds to its cost. Density: Quicklime is more dense than hydrated lime. This means for the same volume, quicklime has a higher weight. For large purchases, this can make quicklime cheaper per tonne because there are lower transportation and storage costs. Application: The overall cost comparison also depends on the specific application. For example, hydrated lime is often sold in smaller bags for specific uses, while quicklime might be purchased in bulk for industrial purposes. Product availability: Quicklime is the raw material, while hydrated lime is a finished product that has been chemically altered, which also contributes to a higher per-unit price.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: Firering, by my estimations are sat on roughly $2.44m - $1,000,000 (Ricca) - $1,154,790 (Recent raise of £0.86m) - $290,000 (Expected with Ricca selling asset) The next 2 tranches come to $1,963,334. I’m assuming some of the remaining will go towards running costs over the next 3 months. That really only leaves the July 31st Tranche of $1,033,333 to find in ~5 months. More time for them to get Kiln 2 producing, more time for Kiln 1 to add to the inventory that already sits around 5000t (~$1,000.000 at $200/t). =============== References/Workings Below: =============== Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/updated-agreement-to-acquire-quicklime-project-l3ar5frikeolmlb.html - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and - an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333. “Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to announce that it has received US$1m in full and final settlement of all debts and claims owed by Ricca. In addition, Firering announces the closing of a placing and subscription raising a further £0.86 m (the "Placing" and "Subscription"). “ Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/fundraising-and-limeco-operations-update-60tbcon53oov2dy.html - Received $1,000,000 from Ricca - £860,000 from placing which is roughly $1,154,790 “As stated previously, Firering also expects that Ricca will make a distribution of net proceeds to Ricca's shareholders following completion of the sale of a subsidiary asset for A$4.4 million (approximately £2.2 million), subject to an adjustment of up to A$332,000 (approximately £166,000) payable to Skylark Minerals Limited (ASX: SKM) (Skylark). Firering holds a 10.6 percent shareholding in Ricca.” Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/ricca-resources-us1m-settlement-finalised-h6cfhczw7semxmk.html - £2.2m minus the £166,000 is £2,034,000 - 10.6 % of £2m is £215,604 - That’s roughly $290,000

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: The shareholder loan of US$104,546,336‡ is what will be paid back to shareholders (Firering, Clearglass Investments Limited ("Clearglass") and Kai Group Ltd) once, I assume, Limeco is fully operational and profitable. It's an asset and would be paid back before dividends with the benefit of avoiding tax. In simplistic terms, it's tax free dividends. Currently Firering have 30.7% of that asset, hopefully rising to 45% by July. Money in the bank for the January tranche, we have until 30th April to get the next payment together. Hopefully by selling quicklime etc, or Bank loan. Last report would be a raise. · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and · an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333.

data.author: Piemaker
data.content: When Mr Cohen states in February 25, that the first kiln is fired up, with the rest online by the end of 25. And here we are, 1 Kiln that could run at 40t a day, taken offline and optimised, now doing 45t a day. The rest of the kilns?. Well we know in September they were waiting for parts from India, for kiln 2, the rest? And this set up is new and fandangelled, and will increase production. So February was a sales pitch to get money in. The reality is one kiln works grossing $9-10k gross, the time and money spent on modernisation has never been clear, but now looks happless. How are they going to fund the final 2 tranches? We know the next one is taken care of, but then? Because they sure aren’t making any money. The bank loan, $4m. How much revenue does it make to make at what margin makes this affordable? The $80k a year logistics profit, the net on the 34.5% share of revenue $3k a day gross. Or are they going to have to come back cap in hand for more? It’s going to take a lot more than 1 kiln and a good sales pitch. Perhaps it’s time for a change in leadership.

data.author: Lithman
data.content: Google search: Hydrated lime is generally more expensive than quicklime per pound because it is a processed product, but quicklime may be more cost-effective for large-scale use due to its higher density, which lowers transportation costs. The final price depends on quantity, brand, and application. Processing cost: Hydrated lime is quicklime with water added, a processing step that adds to its cost. Density: Quicklime is more dense than hydrated lime. This means for the same volume, quicklime has a higher weight. For large purchases, this can make quicklime cheaper per tonne because there are lower transportation and storage costs. Application: The overall cost comparison also depends on the specific application. For example, hydrated lime is often sold in smaller bags for specific uses, while quicklime might be purchased in bulk for industrial purposes. Product availability: Quicklime is the raw material, while hydrated lime is a finished product that has been chemically altered, which also contributes to a higher per-unit price.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: Firering, by my estimations are sat on roughly $2.44m - $1,000,000 (Ricca) - $1,154,790 (Recent raise of £0.86m) - $290,000 (Expected with Ricca selling asset) The next 2 tranches come to $1,963,334. I’m assuming some of the remaining will go towards running costs over the next 3 months. That really only leaves the July 31st Tranche of $1,033,333 to find in ~5 months. More time for them to get Kiln 2 producing, more time for Kiln 1 to add to the inventory that already sits around 5000t (~$1,000.000 at $200/t). =============== References/Workings Below: =============== Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/updated-agreement-to-acquire-quicklime-project-l3ar5frikeolmlb.html - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and - an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333. “Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to announce that it has received US$1m in full and final settlement of all debts and claims owed by Ricca. In addition, Firering announces the closing of a placing and subscription raising a further £0.86 m (the "Placing" and "Subscription"). “ Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/fundraising-and-limeco-operations-update-60tbcon53oov2dy.html - Received $1,000,000 from Ricca - £860,000 from placing which is roughly $1,154,790 “As stated previously, Firering also expects that Ricca will make a distribution of net proceeds to Ricca's shareholders following completion of the sale of a subsidiary asset for A$4.4 million (approximately £2.2 million), subject to an adjustment of up to A$332,000 (approximately £166,000) payable to Skylark Minerals Limited (ASX: SKM) (Skylark). Firering holds a 10.6 percent shareholding in Ricca.” Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/ricca-resources-us1m-settlement-finalised-h6cfhczw7semxmk.html - £2.2m minus the £166,000 is £2,034,000 - 10.6 % of £2m is £215,604 - That’s roughly $290,000

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: "So another raise, followed by another one" Potentially, going by their continued track record it seems likely. They've mentioned the bank loan a few times but then resorted to raises. We need that second kiln operating at a decent level and hopefully Firering can then secure the bank loan. "with a return to target price of 1.25 inside 3 years (based on warrants)" Can you elaborate? Warrants look like a drop in the ocean. "So a 2/5 dilution in the next 6 months. In effect the baseline price is 0.75." As far as I'm concerned, nothing will matter unless they get these kilns working nearer to their target values (80-100 tonnes/day). With the kilns operating and limeco able to start repaying the shareholders loan (~$45m assuming the last tranche goes through) the Mcap of £4.4m is quite undervalued, dispite the potential for dilution. Your numbers seem to suggest that nothing is going to change apart from dilution. I'm all for hearing everyones opinions but I'd rather know how you came to them, that's where the meat is.

data.content: So another raise, followed by another one, with a return to target price of 1.25 inside 3 years (based on warrants). So a 2/5 dilution in the next 6 months. In effect the baseline price is 0.75.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: The shareholder loan of US$104,546,336‡ is what will be paid back to shareholders (Firering, Clearglass Investments Limited ("Clearglass") and Kai Group Ltd) once, I assume, Limeco is fully operational and profitable. It's an asset and would be paid back before dividends with the benefit of avoiding tax. In simplistic terms, it's tax free dividends. Currently Firering have 30.7% of that asset, hopefully rising to 45% by July. Money in the bank for the January tranche, we have until 30th April to get the next payment together. Hopefully by selling quicklime etc, or Bank loan. Last report would be a raise. · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and · an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333.

data.content: When Mr Cohen states in February 25, that the first kiln is fired up, with the rest online by the end of 25. data.author: BenBaccon
data.content: Great news indeed, but I'm surprised by the muted response. The possibility of a placing to pay the January 2026 Limeco option has been dragging the share price down for some time. Now the finance for that is sorted, it means we have almost 6 months until the next Limeco option payment at the end of April. With kiln 1 operating at 55% and kiln 2 coming on line in December, then come the new year we'll be operating at a profit and generating a significant income stream ($5M per annum?) The original plan was a loan from a Zambian bank to cover the Limeco options ($2M outstanding) Surely this should now be approved given the consistent revenue being generated? I'm looking forward to an update on the kiln 2 progress, and then the activation of kilns 3 and 4 in the new year, at which point we could be generating around $10M per annum. Then the remaining 4 kilns can be activated and the concrete facility constructed.

data.author: Lithman
data.content: Google search: Hydrated lime is generally more expensive than quicklime per pound because it is a processed product, but quicklime may be more cost-effective for large-scale use due to its higher density, which lowers transportation costs. The final price depends on quantity, brand, and application. Processing cost: Hydrated lime is quicklime with water added, a processing step that adds to its cost. Density: Quicklime is more dense than hydrated lime. This means for the same volume, quicklime has a higher weight. For large purchases, this can make quicklime cheaper per tonne because there are lower transportation and storage costs. Application: The overall cost comparison also depends on the specific application. For example, hydrated lime is often sold in smaller bags for specific uses, while quicklime might be purchased in bulk for industrial purposes. Product availability: Quicklime is the raw material, while hydrated lime is a finished product that has been chemically altered, which also contributes to a higher per-unit price.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: Firering, by my estimations are sat on roughly $2.44m - $1,000,000 (Ricca) - $1,154,790 (Recent raise of £0.86m) - $290,000 (Expected with Ricca selling asset) The next 2 tranches come to $1,963,334. I’m assuming some of the remaining will go towards running costs over the next 3 months. That really only leaves the July 31st Tranche of $1,033,333 to find in ~5 months. More time for them to get Kiln 2 producing, more time for Kiln 1 to add to the inventory that already sits around 5000t (~$1,000.000 at $200/t). =============== References/Workings Below: =============== Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/updated-agreement-to-acquire-quicklime-project-l3ar5frikeolmlb.html - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and - an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333. “Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to announce that it has received US$1m in full and final settlement of all debts and claims owed by Ricca. In addition, Firering announces the closing of a placing and subscription raising a further £0.86 m (the "Placing" and "Subscription"). “ Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/fundraising-and-limeco-operations-update-60tbcon53oov2dy.html - Received $1,000,000 from Ricca - £860,000 from placing which is roughly $1,154,790 “As stated previously, Firering also expects that Ricca will make a distribution of net proceeds to Ricca's shareholders following completion of the sale of a subsidiary asset for A$4.4 million (approximately £2.2 million), subject to an adjustment of up to A$332,000 (approximately £166,000) payable to Skylark Minerals Limited (ASX: SKM) (Skylark). Firering holds a 10.6 percent shareholding in Ricca.” Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/ricca-resources-us1m-settlement-finalised-h6cfhczw7semxmk.html - £2.2m minus the £166,000 is £2,034,000 - 10.6 % of £2m is £215,604 - That’s roughly $290,000

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: "So another raise, followed by another one" Potentially, going by their continued track record it seems likely. They've mentioned the bank loan a few times but then resorted to raises. We need that second kiln operating at a decent level and hopefully Firering can then secure the bank loan. "with a return to target price of 1.25 inside 3 years (based on warrants)" Can you elaborate? Warrants look like a drop in the ocean. "So a 2/5 dilution in the next 6 months. In effect the baseline price is 0.75." As far as I'm concerned, nothing will matter unless they get these kilns working nearer to their target values (80-100 tonnes/day). With the kilns operating and limeco able to start repaying the shareholders loan (~$45m assuming the last tranche goes through) the Mcap of £4.4m is quite undervalued, dispite the potential for dilution. Your numbers seem to suggest that nothing is going to change apart from dilution. I'm all for hearing everyones opinions but I'd rather know how you came to them, that's where the meat is.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: The shareholder loan of US$104,546,336‡ is what will be paid back to shareholders (Firering, Clearglass Investments Limited ("Clearglass") and Kai Group Ltd) once, I assume, Limeco is fully operational and profitable. It's an asset and would be paid back before dividends with the benefit of avoiding tax. In simplistic terms, it's tax free dividends. Currently Firering have 30.7% of that asset, hopefully rising to 45% by July. Money in the bank for the January tranche, we have until 30th April to get the next payment together. Hopefully by selling quicklime etc, or Bank loan. Last report would be a raise. · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and · an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333.

data.author: Piemaker
data.content: When Mr Cohen states in February 25, that the first kiln is fired up, with the rest online by the end of 25. And here we are, 1 Kiln that could run at 40t a day, taken offline and optimised, now doing 45t a day. The rest of the kilns?. Well we know in September they were waiting for parts from India, for kiln 2, the rest? And this set up is new and fandangelled, and will increase production. So February was a sales pitch to get money in. The reality is one kiln works grossing $9-10k gross, the time and money spent on modernisation has never been clear, but now looks happless. How are they going to fund the final 2 tranches? We know the next one is taken care of, but then? Because they sure aren’t making any money. The bank loan, $4m. How much revenue does it make to make at what margin makes this affordable? The $80k a year logistics profit, the net on the 34.5% share of revenue $3k a day gross. Or are they going to have to come back cap in hand for more? It’s going to take a lot more than 1 kiln and a good sales pitch. Perhaps it’s time for a change in leadership.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: Firering, by my estimations are sat on roughly $2.44m - $1,000,000 (Ricca) - $1,154,790 (Recent raise of £0.86m) - $290,000 (Expected with Ricca selling asset) The next 2 tranches come to $1,963,334. I’m assuming some of the remaining will go towards running costs over the next 3 months. That really only leaves the July 31st Tranche of $1,033,333 to find in ~5 months. More time for them to get Kiln 2 producing, more time for Kiln 1 to add to the inventory that already sits around 5000t (~$1,000.000 at $200/t). =============== References/Workings Below: =============== Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/updated-agreement-to-acquire-quicklime-project-l3ar5frikeolmlb.html - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and - an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333. “Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to announce that it has received US$1m in full and final settlement of all debts and claims owed by Ricca. In addition, Firering announces the closing of a placing and subscription raising a further £0.86 m (the "Placing" and "Subscription"). “ Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/fundraising-and-limeco-operations-update-60tbcon53oov2dy.html - Received $1,000,000 from Ricca - £860,000 from placing which is roughly $1,154,790 “As stated previously, Firering also expects that Ricca will make a distribution of net proceeds to Ricca's shareholders following completion of the sale of a subsidiary asset for A$4.4 million (approximately £2.2 million), subject to an adjustment of up to A$332,000 (approximately £166,000) payable to Skylark Minerals Limited (ASX: SKM) (Skylark). Firering holds a 10.6 percent shareholding in Ricca.” Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/ricca-resources-us1m-settlement-finalised-h6cfhczw7semxmk.html - £2.2m minus the £166,000 is £2,034,000 - 10.6 % of £2m is £215,604 - That’s roughly $290,000

data.content: "So another raise, followed by another one" Potentially, going by their continued track record it seems likely. They've mentioned the bank loan a few times but then resorted to raises. We need that second kiln operating at a decent level and hopefully Firering can then secure the bank loan. "with a return to target price of 1.25 inside 3 years (based on warrants)" Can you elaborate? Warrants look like a drop in the ocean. "So a 2/5 dilution in the next 6 months. With the kilns operating and limeco able to start repaying the shareholders loan (~$45m assuming the last tranche goes through) the Mcap of £4.4m is quite undervalued, dispite the potential for dilution. Your numbers seem to suggest that nothing is going to change apart from dilution. I'm all for hearing everyones opinions but I'd rather know how you came to them, that's where the meat is.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: The shareholder loan of US$104,546,336‡ is what will be paid back to shareholders (Firering, Clearglass Investments Limited ("Clearglass") and Kai Group Ltd) once, I assume, Limeco is fully operational and profitable. It's an asset and would be paid back before dividends with the benefit of avoiding tax. In simplistic terms, it's tax free dividends. Currently Firering have 30.7% of that asset, hopefully rising to 45% by July. Money in the bank for the January tranche, we have until 30th April to get the next payment together. Hopefully by selling quicklime etc, or Bank loan. Last report would be a raise. · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and · an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333.

data.author: Lithman
data.content: Google search: Hydrated lime is generally more expensive than quicklime per pound because it is a processed product, but quicklime may be more cost-effective for large-scale use due to its higher density, which lowers transportation costs. The final price depends on quantity, brand, and application. Processing cost: Hydrated lime is quicklime with water added, a processing step that adds to its cost. Density: Quicklime is more dense than hydrated lime. This means for the same volume, quicklime has a higher weight. For large purchases, this can make quicklime cheaper per tonne because there are lower transportation and storage costs. Application: The overall cost comparison also depends on the specific application. For example, hydrated lime is often sold in smaller bags for specific uses, while quicklime might be purchased in bulk for industrial purposes. Product availability: Quicklime is the raw material, while hydrated lime is a finished product that has been chemically altered, which also contributes to a higher per-unit price.

More time for them to get Kiln 2 producing, more time for Kiln 1 to add to the inventory that already sits around 5000t (~$1,000.000 at $200/t). =============== References/Workings Below: =============== Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/updated-agreement-to-acquire-quicklime-project-l3ar5frikeolmlb.html - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and - an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333. “Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to announce that it has received US$1m in full and final settlement of all debts and claims owed by Ricca. In addition, Firering announces the closing of a placing and subscription raising a further £0.86 m (the "Placing" and "Subscription"). “ Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/fundraising-and-limeco-operations-update-60tbcon53oov2dy.html - Received $1,000,000 from Ricca - £860,000 from placing which is roughly $1,154,790 “As stated previously, Firering also expects that Ricca will make a distribution of net proceeds to Ricca's shareholders following completion of the sale of a subsidiary asset for A$4.4 million (approximately £2.2 million), subject to an adjustment of up to A$332,000 (approximately £166,000) payable to Skylark Minerals Limited (ASX: SKM) (Skylark). Firering holds a 10.6 percent shareholding in Ricca.” Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/ricca-resources-us1m-settlement-finalised-h6cfhczw7semxmk.html - £2.2m minus the £166,000 is £2,034,000 - 10.6 % of £2m is £215,604 - That’s roughly $290,000

Then the remaining 4 kilns can be activated and the concrete facility constructed.

data.author: Lithman
data.content: Google search: Hydrated lime is generally more expensive than quicklime per pound because it is a processed product, but quicklime may be more cost-effective for large-scale use due to its higher density, which lowers transportation costs. The final price depends on quantity, brand, and application. Processing cost: Hydrated lime is quicklime with water added, a processing step that adds to its cost. Density: Quicklime is more dense than hydrated lime. This means for the same volume, quicklime has a higher weight. For large purchases, this can make quicklime cheaper per tonne because there are lower transportation and storage costs. Application: The overall cost comparison also depends on the specific application. For example, hydrated lime is often sold in smaller bags for specific uses, while quicklime might be purchased in bulk for industrial purposes. Product availability: Quicklime is the raw material, while hydrated lime is a finished product that has been chemically altered, which also contributes to a higher per-unit price.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: The shareholder loan of US$104,546,336‡ is what will be paid back to shareholders (Firering, Clearglass Investments Limited ("Clearglass") and Kai Group Ltd) once, I assume, Limeco is fully operational and profitable. It's an asset and would be paid back before dividends with the benefit of avoiding tax. In simplistic terms, it's tax free dividends. Currently Firering have 30.7% of that asset, hopefully rising to 45% by July. Money in the bank for the January tranche, we have until 30th April to get the next payment together. Hopefully by selling quicklime etc, or Bank loan. Last report would be a raise. · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and · an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333.

data.content: When Mr Cohen states in February 25, that the first kiln is fired up, with the rest online by the end of 25. data.author: Lithman
data.content: Google search: Hydrated lime is generally more expensive than quicklime per pound because it is a processed product, but quicklime may be more cost-effective for large-scale use due to its higher density, which lowers transportation costs. The final price depends on quantity, brand, and application. Processing cost: Hydrated lime is quicklime with water added, a processing step that adds to its cost. Density: Quicklime is more dense than hydrated lime. This means for the same volume, quicklime has a higher weight. For large purchases, this can make quicklime cheaper per tonne because there are lower transportation and storage costs. Application: The overall cost comparison also depends on the specific application. For example, hydrated lime is often sold in smaller bags for specific uses, while quicklime might be purchased in bulk for industrial purposes. Product availability: Quicklime is the raw material, while hydrated lime is a finished product that has been chemically altered, which also contributes to a higher per-unit price.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: Firering, by my estimations are sat on roughly $2.44m - $1,000,000 (Ricca) - $1,154,790 (Recent raise of £0.86m) - $290,000 (Expected with Ricca selling asset) The next 2 tranches come to $1,963,334. I’m assuming some of the remaining will go towards running costs over the next 3 months. That really only leaves the July 31st Tranche of $1,033,333 to find in ~5 months. More time for them to get Kiln 2 producing, more time for Kiln 1 to add to the inventory that already sits around 5000t (~$1,000.000 at $200/t). =============== References/Workings Below: =============== Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/updated-agreement-to-acquire-quicklime-project-l3ar5frikeolmlb.html - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and - an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333. “Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to announce that it has received US$1m in full and final settlement of all debts and claims owed by Ricca. In addition, Firering announces the closing of a placing and subscription raising a further £0.86 m (the "Placing" and "Subscription"). “ Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/fundraising-and-limeco-operations-update-60tbcon53oov2dy.html - Received $1,000,000 from Ricca - £860,000 from placing which is roughly $1,154,790 “As stated previously, Firering also expects that Ricca will make a distribution of net proceeds to Ricca's shareholders following completion of the sale of a subsidiary asset for A$4.4 million (approximately £2.2 million), subject to an adjustment of up to A$332,000 (approximately £166,000) payable to Skylark Minerals Limited (ASX: SKM) (Skylark). Firering holds a 10.6 percent shareholding in Ricca.” Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/ricca-resources-us1m-settlement-finalised-h6cfhczw7semxmk.html - £2.2m minus the £166,000 is £2,034,000 - 10.6 % of £2m is £215,604 - That’s roughly $290,000

"with a return to target price of 1.25 inside 3 years (based on warrants)" Can you elaborate? Warrants look like a drop in the ocean. "So a 2/5 dilution in the next 6 months. In effect the baseline price is 0.75." As far as I'm concerned, nothing will matter unless they get these kilns working nearer to their target values (80-100 tonnes/day). With the kilns operating and limeco able to start repaying the shareholders loan (~$45m assuming the last tranche goes through) the Mcap of £4.4m is quite undervalued, dispite the potential for dilution. Your numbers seem to suggest that nothing is going to change apart from dilution. I'm all for hearing everyones opinions but I'd rather know how you came to them, that's where the meat is.

data.content: The shareholder loan of US$104,546,336‡ is what will be paid back to shareholders (Firering, Clearglass Investments Limited ("Clearglass") and Kai Group Ltd) once, I assume, Limeco is fully operational and profitable. Currently Firering have 30.7% of that asset, hopefully rising to 45% by July. Money in the bank for the January tranche, we have until 30th April to get the next payment together. Hopefully by selling quicklime etc, or Bank loan. Last report would be a raise. · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and · an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333.

data.title: Operations Update
data.full_content:
Today 07:00
RNS Number : 3017S
Firering Strategic Minerals PLC
10 February 2026
Firering Strategic Minerals plc / EPIC: FRG / Market: AIM / Sector: Mining
10 February 2026
Firering Strategic Minerals plc
("Firering" or "the Company")
Operations Updates
Kiln 2 Hot Commissioned & Commercial Momentum Building
Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to provide an update on its producing lime asset in Zambia, Limeco Resources Limited ("Limeco").
Highlights
·
Completed hot commissioning of Kiln 2, which is now entering the optimisation phase.
·
Progression toward sustained multi-kiln production, strengthening operating leverage, cash generation potential and strategic and financing optionality.
·
Growing commercial momentum underpinned by successful product validation, international orders, and further opportunities under discussion.
·
Completed the exercise of the third tranche of the Option to acquire a further 5.5% interest in Limeco, taking its interest to 36.2%.
Firering Chairman and Interim CEO, Youval Rasin, commented:
"Hot commissioning of Kiln 2 is a further delivery milestone for Limeco and demonstrates the operational discipline now in place across the site. Applying the learnings from Kiln 1 enables us to have a more predictable, repeatable ramp-up as we scale to a multi-kiln operation. Notably, each additional kiln brought into stable production, materially strengthens the business and expands its strategic optionality."
DETAILS
Limeco Operations
Limeco has completed the hot commissioning of Kiln 2, during which saleable material was produced. As with the first kiln, production from Kiln 2 is expected to ramp up over an approximate three-month optimisation period, during which operating parameters will be progressively refined to achieve consistent output with consistent quality and reliability. This optimisation phase is standard practice in the industry.
Kiln 2 incorporates the operational learnings from the ramp-up of Kiln 1, with targeted improvements to the burner system, airflow management, heat distribution and monitoring protocols, supporting a faster and more predictable path to steady-state production.
Each additional kiln brought into stable operation materially strengthens operating leverage, cash generation potential and the overall resilience of the Project. In this context, the successful hot commissioning of Kiln 2 represents a further step in strengthening Firering's strategic and financing optionality as production capacity continues to increase.
Limeco Sales and Customer Engagement
Commercial momentum continues to build, with growing interest in Limeco's product range and encouraging developments across local and regional markets. Following a stringent validation process involving laboratory testing, bulk sampling, site inspections and trial orders, Limeco secured a 600t order from a major international mining group operating in Zambia. This order is currently being fulfilled, alongside a similar-sized order for material destined for clients in Zimbabwe. Engagements with additional prospective customers are ongoing, and Limeco is now well positioned to compete in tenders for longer-term supply contracts.
Limeco Option Agreement
In line with the Limeco Option Agreement (the "Option") (see RNS dated
28 May
2024)
, Firering has completed the exercise of the third tranche of the Option to acquire a further 5.5% interest in Limeco, taking its shareholding in Limeco to 36.2%.
ENDS
For further information visit www.fireringplc.com or contact:
Firering Strategic Minerals
Vassilios Carellas
E: info@firering-holdings.com
SPARK Advisory Partners Limited (Nominated Adviser)
Neil Baldwin / James Keeshan
T: +44 20 3368 3550
Shard Capital Partners LLP (Joint Broker)
Damon Heath / Erik Woolgar
T: +44 20 7186 9950
St Brides Partners Limited (Financial PR)
Isabel de Salis / Susie Geliher
E: firering@stbridespartners.co.uk
Notes
Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG) is an Africa-focused producer and developer of industrial and critical minerals. The Company's near-term focus is the ramp-up of production at the Limeco lime project in Zambia, where Firering holds a 36.2% interest with an option to increase this to 45%. Once fully optimised, Limeco is expected to be among the largest lime operations in the region, supplying major copper producers in the Central African Copperbelt and gold producers in Zimbabwe. Firering's portfolio also includes the highly prospective Atex Lithium-Tantalum Project in northern Côte d'Ivoire.

data.author: Lithman
data.content: Google search: Hydrated lime is generally more expensive than quicklime per pound because it is a processed product, but quicklime may be more cost-effective for large-scale use due to its higher density, which lowers transportation costs. The final price depends on quantity, brand, and application. Processing cost: Hydrated lime is quicklime with water added, a processing step that adds to its cost. Density: Quicklime is more dense than hydrated lime. This means for the same volume, quicklime has a higher weight. For large purchases, this can make quicklime cheaper per tonne because there are lower transportation and storage costs. Application: The overall cost comparison also depends on the specific application. For example, hydrated lime is often sold in smaller bags for specific uses, while quicklime might be purchased in bulk for industrial purposes. Product availability: Quicklime is the raw material, while hydrated lime is a finished product that has been chemically altered, which also contributes to a higher per-unit price.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: Firering, by my estimations are sat on roughly $2.44m - $1,000,000 (Ricca) - $1,154,790 (Recent raise of £0.86m) - $290,000 (Expected with Ricca selling asset) The next 2 tranches come to $1,963,334. I’m assuming some of the remaining will go towards running costs over the next 3 months. That really only leaves the July 31st Tranche of $1,033,333 to find in ~5 months. More time for them to get Kiln 2 producing, more time for Kiln 1 to add to the inventory that already sits around 5000t (~$1,000.000 at $200/t). =============== References/Workings Below: =============== Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/updated-agreement-to-acquire-quicklime-project-l3ar5frikeolmlb.html - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and - an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333. “Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to announce that it has received US$1m in full and final settlement of all debts and claims owed by Ricca. In addition, Firering announces the closing of a placing and subscription raising a further £0.86 m (the "Placing" and "Subscription"). “ Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/fundraising-and-limeco-operations-update-60tbcon53oov2dy.html - Received $1,000,000 from Ricca - £860,000 from placing which is roughly $1,154,790 “As stated previously, Firering also expects that Ricca will make a distribution of net proceeds to Ricca's shareholders following completion of the sale of a subsidiary asset for A$4.4 million (approximately £2.2 million), subject to an adjustment of up to A$332,000 (approximately £166,000) payable to Skylark Minerals Limited (ASX: SKM) (Skylark). Firering holds a 10.6 percent shareholding in Ricca.” Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/ricca-resources-us1m-settlement-finalised-h6cfhczw7semxmk.html - £2.2m minus the £166,000 is £2,034,000 - 10.6 % of £2m is £215,604 - That’s roughly $290,000

data.content: "So another raise, followed by another one" Potentially, going by their continued track record it seems likely. They've mentioned the bank loan a few times but then resorted to raises. We need that second kiln operating at a decent level and hopefully Firering can then secure the bank loan. "with a return to target price of 1.25 inside 3 years (based on warrants)" Can you elaborate? Warrants look like a drop in the ocean. "So a 2/5 dilution in the next 6 months. In effect the baseline price is 0.75." As far as I'm concerned, nothing will matter unless they get these kilns working nearer to their target values (80-100 tonnes/day). With the kilns operating and limeco able to start repaying the shareholders loan (~$45m assuming the last tranche goes through) the Mcap of £4.4m is quite undervalued, dispite the potential for dilution. Your numbers seem to suggest that nothing is going to change apart from dilution. I'm all for hearing everyones opinions but I'd rather know how you came to them, that's where the meat is.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: The shareholder loan of US$104,546,336‡ is what will be paid back to shareholders (Firering, Clearglass Investments Limited ("Clearglass") and Kai Group Ltd) once, I assume, Limeco is fully operational and profitable. It's an asset and would be paid back before dividends with the benefit of avoiding tax. In simplistic terms, it's tax free dividends. Currently Firering have 30.7% of that asset, hopefully rising to 45% by July. Money in the bank for the January tranche, we have until 30th April to get the next payment together. Hopefully by selling quicklime etc, or Bank loan. Last report would be a raise. · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and · an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333.

data.author: Piemaker
data.content: When Mr Cohen states in February 25, that the first kiln is fired up, with the rest online by the end of 25. And here we are, 1 Kiln that could run at 40t a day, taken offline and optimised, now doing 45t a day. The rest of the kilns?. Well we know in September they were waiting for parts from India, for kiln 2, the rest? And this set up is new and fandangelled, and will increase production. So February was a sales pitch to get money in. The reality is one kiln works grossing $9-10k gross, the time and money spent on modernisation has never been clear, but now looks happless. How are they going to fund the final 2 tranches? We know the next one is taken care of, but then? Because they sure aren’t making any money. The bank loan, $4m. How much revenue does it make to make at what margin makes this affordable? The $80k a year logistics profit, the net on the 34.5% share of revenue $3k a day gross. Or are they going to have to come back cap in hand for more? It’s going to take a lot more than 1 kiln and a good sales pitch. Perhaps it’s time for a change in leadership.

data.author: Lithman
data.content: Google search: Hydrated lime is generally more expensive than quicklime per pound because it is a processed product, but quicklime may be more cost-effective for large-scale use due to its higher density, which lowers transportation costs. The final price depends on quantity, brand, and application. Processing cost: Hydrated lime is quicklime with water added, a processing step that adds to its cost. Density: Quicklime is more dense than hydrated lime. This means for the same volume, quicklime has a higher weight. For large purchases, this can make quicklime cheaper per tonne because there are lower transportation and storage costs. Application: The overall cost comparison also depends on the specific application. For example, hydrated lime is often sold in smaller bags for specific uses, while quicklime might be purchased in bulk for industrial purposes. Product availability: Quicklime is the raw material, while hydrated lime is a finished product that has been chemically altered, which also contributes to a higher per-unit price.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: Firering, by my estimations are sat on roughly $2.44m - $1,000,000 (Ricca) - $1,154,790 (Recent raise of £0.86m) - $290,000 (Expected with Ricca selling asset) The next 2 tranches come to $1,963,334. I’m assuming some of the remaining will go towards running costs over the next 3 months. That really only leaves the July 31st Tranche of $1,033,333 to find in ~5 months. More time for them to get Kiln 2 producing, more time for Kiln 1 to add to the inventory that already sits around 5000t (~$1,000.000 at $200/t). =============== References/Workings Below: =============== Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/updated-agreement-to-acquire-quicklime-project-l3ar5frikeolmlb.html - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and - an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333. “Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to announce that it has received US$1m in full and final settlement of all debts and claims owed by Ricca. In addition, Firering announces the closing of a placing and subscription raising a further £0.86 m (the "Placing" and "Subscription"). “ Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/fundraising-and-limeco-operations-update-60tbcon53oov2dy.html - Received $1,000,000 from Ricca - £860,000 from placing which is roughly $1,154,790 “As stated previously, Firering also expects that Ricca will make a distribution of net proceeds to Ricca's shareholders following completion of the sale of a subsidiary asset for A$4.4 million (approximately £2.2 million), subject to an adjustment of up to A$332,000 (approximately £166,000) payable to Skylark Minerals Limited (ASX: SKM) (Skylark). Firering holds a 10.6 percent shareholding in Ricca.” Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/ricca-resources-us1m-settlement-finalised-h6cfhczw7semxmk.html - £2.2m minus the £166,000 is £2,034,000 - 10.6 % of £2m is £215,604 - That’s roughly $290,000

data.content: "So another raise, followed by another one" Potentially, going by their continued track record it seems likely. They've mentioned the bank loan a few times but then resorted to raises. We need that second kiln operating at a decent level and hopefully Firering can then secure the bank loan. "with a return to target price of 1.25 inside 3 years (based on warrants)" Can you elaborate? Warrants look like a drop in the ocean. "So a 2/5 dilution in the next 6 months. In effect the baseline price is 0.75." As far as I'm concerned, nothing will matter unless they get these kilns working nearer to their target values (80-100 tonnes/day). With the kilns operating and limeco able to start repaying the shareholders loan (~$45m assuming the last tranche goes through) the Mcap of £4.4m is quite undervalued, dispite the potential for dilution. Your numbers seem to suggest that nothing is going to change apart from dilution. I'm all for hearing everyones opinions but I'd rather know how you came to them, that's where the meat is.

data.author: Piemaker
data.content: So another raise, followed by another one, with a return to target price of 1.25 inside 3 years (based on warrants). So a 2/5 dilution in the next 6 months. In effect the baseline price is 0.75.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: The shareholder loan of US$104,546,336‡ is what will be paid back to shareholders (Firering, Clearglass Investments Limited ("Clearglass") and Kai Group Ltd) once, I assume, Limeco is fully operational and profitable. It's an asset and would be paid back before dividends with the benefit of avoiding tax. In simplistic terms, it's tax free dividends. Currently Firering have 30.7% of that asset, hopefully rising to 45% by July. Money in the bank for the January tranche, we have until 30th April to get the next payment together. Hopefully by selling quicklime etc, or Bank loan. Last report would be a raise. · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and · an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333.

data.author: Piemaker
data.content: When Mr Cohen states in February 25, that the first kiln is fired up, with the rest online by the end of 25. And here we are, 1 Kiln that could run at 40t a day, taken offline and optimised, now doing 45t a day. The rest of the kilns?. Well we know in September they were waiting for parts from India, for kiln 2, the rest? And this set up is new and fandangelled, and will increase production. So February was a sales pitch to get money in. The reality is one kiln works grossing $9-10k gross, the time and money spent on modernisation has never been clear, but now looks happless. How are they going to fund the final 2 tranches? We know the next one is taken care of, but then? Because they sure aren’t making any money. The bank loan, $4m. How much revenue does it make to make at what margin makes this affordable? The $80k a year logistics profit, the net on the 34.5% share of revenue $3k a day gross. Or are they going to have to come back cap in hand for more? It’s going to take a lot more than 1 kiln and a good sales pitch. Perhaps it’s time for a change in leadership.

data.author: Lithman
data.content: Google search: Hydrated lime is generally more expensive than quicklime per pound because it is a processed product, but quicklime may be more cost-effective for large-scale use due to its higher density, which lowers transportation costs. The final price depends on quantity, brand, and application. Processing cost: Hydrated lime is quicklime with water added, a processing step that adds to its cost. Density: Quicklime is more dense than hydrated lime. This means for the same volume, quicklime has a higher weight. For large purchases, this can make quicklime cheaper per tonne because there are lower transportation and storage costs. Application: The overall cost comparison also depends on the specific application. For example, hydrated lime is often sold in smaller bags for specific uses, while quicklime might be purchased in bulk for industrial purposes. Product availability: Quicklime is the raw material, while hydrated lime is a finished product that has been chemically altered, which also contributes to a higher per-unit price.

data.author: Jamoe
data.content: Firering, by my estimations are sat on roughly $2.44m - $1,000,000 (Ricca) - $1,154,790 (Recent raise of £0.86m) - $290,000 (Expected with Ricca selling asset) The next 2 tranches come to $1,963,334. I’m assuming some of the remaining will go towards running costs over the next 3 months. That really only leaves the July 31st Tranche of $1,033,333 to find in ~5 months. More time for them to get Kiln 2 producing, more time for Kiln 1 to add to the inventory that already sits around 5000t (~$1,000.000 at $200/t). =============== References/Workings Below: =============== Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/updated-agreement-to-acquire-quicklime-project-l3ar5frikeolmlb.html - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; - an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and - an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333. “Firering Strategic Minerals plc (AIM: FRG), a producer of lime products and explorer of critical minerals, is pleased to announce that it has received US$1m in full and final settlement of all debts and claims owed by Ricca. In addition, Firering announces the closing of a placing and subscription raising a further £0.86 m (the "Placing" and "Subscription"). “ Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/fundraising-and-limeco-operations-update-60tbcon53oov2dy.html - Received $1,000,000 from Ricca - £860,000 from placing which is roughly $1,154,790 “As stated previously, Firering also expects that Ricca will make a distribution of net proceeds to Ricca's shareholders following completion of the sale of a subsidiary asset for A$4.4 million (approximately £2.2 million), subject to an adjustment of up to A$332,000 (approximately £166,000) payable to Skylark Minerals Limited (ASX: SKM) (Skylark). Firering holds a 10.6 percent shareholding in Ricca.” Ref: https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/FRG/ricca-resources-us1m-settlement-finalised-h6cfhczw7semxmk.html - £2.2m minus the £166,000 is £2,034,000 - 10.6 % of £2m is £215,604 - That’s roughly $290,000

Currently Firering have 30.7% of that asset, hopefully rising to 45% by July. Money in the bank for the January tranche, we have until 30th April to get the next payment together. Hopefully by selling quicklime etc, or Bank loan. Last report would be a raise. · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 January 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; · an option to acquire a 5.5% interest no later than 30 April 2026 for a payment of US$981,667; and · an option to acquire a 3.3% interest no later than 31 July 2026 for a payment of US$1,033,333.

company_30s.what_they_do: FRG Ltd supplies quicklime and related industrial chemicals, mainly for construction, steel, and water treatment.
company_30s.why_they_matter: Quicklime is a key raw material in cement, steel, and environmental projects worldwide, and demand is growing with infrastructure and green‑energy initiatives.
company_30s.current_state: The firm is still in the early stages of commercial production, having just finished the second kiln and secured a few medium‑size orders.  It is trading near its all‑time lows, with very limited analyst coverage.

rns_narrative: FRG has just completed the hot commissioning of Kiln 2 and is ramping up production to meet a 600‑tonne order, signalling that the company is moving from setup to cash‑generating operations.
Recent filings show a series of fundraising rounds and a partnership with Limeco that should provide a steady revenue stream once the production line is fully online.
Management is focusing on scaling operations and securing more contracts, while the company’s board has been working on improving governance after a recent board shake‑up.

A positive earnings update once the second kiln is fully operational.
Any announcement of additional funding or a strategic partnership that unlocks new markets.
